column4: I'm trying to set up an sshd. Why are there keys in both ~/.ssh/ and /etc/ssh_host_key ?
The key in /etc is the key for your *machine*, the one in ~ is for your *user*
You don't have to have on in ~/.ssh - but if you do set it up properly it can save you from having to use passwords
Yes - but that key is only used when you SSH from your machine to a remote machine
It's not used 'locally' for local logins
Take a look at http://sial.org/howto/openssh/publickey-auth/

So, for example, when I log into my laptop I need to type a password.  If I then SSH into my server it'll use my key in ~/.ssh and I don't need to type a password again (since I set up my server to accept the key)
I'm setting up an sshd on my computer though, I want to then log into it from my laptop. So I don't use the ~/.ssh/ on my host (computer) but instead on my laptop only (client)?
that's correct!
how will my host know about my login key though?
...well, it's half-correct ;-) on your host 'server' you need an entry in ~/.ssh/authorized_keys
is that only the public key though? won't my host need a private one too?
nope
or does my client have the private one and the host have the public?
The public part goes in $HOST:~/.ssh/authorized_keys, the private part in $CLIENT:~/ssh/id_rsa
what MikeChelen said :)
How do I disallow regular password logins and only allow key logins?
On your server host, change /etc/ssh/sshd_config
it's pretty self-explanatory
I think I have it now, thanks for the help!
You're very welcome, good luck!
Next you'll want to learn about protecting your keys with a password and using ssh-agent
...in case they fall into enemy hands
